B0000029DD|5.0|..may very well be directly related to the fact that it is 10 years old. Some reviewers may be listening to it for the first time now, when after 10 years of age an album may be interpreted with all things current. A simple mind will even compare it to something newer. Others may try to align \\"Grace\\" with a second title from the years 1994-1995 and fail miserably in an adequate comparison. Why?  How can you compare something you have just listened to for the first time to another album you have listened to 20, 200, or 2000 times over?  <br /> <br />A very good freind suggested I listen to it a few months after it was released, and it simply shattered the way I viewed music. At a time where the music industry was being sculpted by MTV-laced \\"Image means everything\\" mentality, (which still continues to this day) this album is a breath of fresh air. There are only a handful of albums where I can instantly recall the very first time and place I listened to an album in its entirety, and this is one of them. The voice, the melodies, the serene atmosphere that surrounded you as the crispness of his words unfold in the air...  <br />\\"I lost myself on a cool damp night...\\" <br /> <br />Shortly thereafter, I gave the album as a gift to the love of my life. Being well aware of my love of music, at no point did I ever try to impose my preferences upon her. Our tastes vary, and often clash. To this day, that is the only time I have ever given a music CD to anyone. <br /> <br />For those who feel their ability to express emotion bottled up inside them at times, this is the album for you. While Jeff brings out somewhat somber and at times desperate feelings across in the songs, I dont feel that it is fair to assume this was to be his \\"Last Goodbye\\" for him musically. The surface was just being scratched. Not overproduced, what you heard on this album is nearly a 100% carbon copy of the songs as played live. That is clearly a credit to the man as a modern day singer-songwriter andcraftsman. Its not a bad thing to let your deepest emotion carry you through the creation of a song, much less on 7 songs(3 are covers). Very few do it today. <br /> <br />I wont deconstruct each song individually, as the entire album needs to be taken as a whole. The entire album speaks for itself. If you have never listened to it before, purchase this album and l-i-s-t-e-n. <br /> <br />Yes this album is one of my desert island discs, and I say it proudly.
1401301363|4.0|Nigella Lawson seems to be the kind of cookbook author who causes people to respond to *her* more than her recipes. I suppose some of that is inevitable, as she has the sort of sultry girl-next-door looks that make us ordinary women contemplate a pact with the devil. But the book is, after all, about the recipes and menu guidance she provides. And I think she does a very good job at that, indeed.<br /><br />This isn't simply a \\"holiday recipes\\" book; Lawson takes the \\"feast\\" theme to heart, and gives recipes for all sorts of occasions in which you're apt to be called to the kitchen. Sure, that includes Thanksgiving and Christmas (which she lumps together), as well as Valentine's day and Rosh Hashanah. But it also includes \\"a Georgian feast\\"  (whose menu includes green beans in herbed yogurt, walnut crescents, and a chicken stuffed with basmati, garlic, and sour cherries), several feasts for making with/for children (the Halloween recipes include a \\"slime soup\\" -- actually a pea and cheese soup), and even a set of dishes to cook for funerals and grieving friends. Not to mention feasts for oneself, such as things to cook at midnight.<br /><br />As you may have gathered, these recipes are organized by the nature of the event, which could get tedious if you wanted to look for all the soup recipes. But isn't that the point?<br /><br />The recipes -- let's get to the meat of the matter, so to speak. While I don't think I'm going to change all my traditional dishes, I'm guaranteed to be inspired by some of her suggestions. I certainly am looking forward to using up my Thanksgiving turkey leftovers in her \\"North American Salad\\" (wild rice, dried cranberries, cooked turkey, cranberry sauce, pecans and parsley). The \\"easy holiday trifle\\" -- which uses dried apricots, cardamom, and a panettone -- is likely to be my contribution to the Christmas buffet. And I'm planning to make the \\"stilton rarebit with walnut and bibb lettuce salad\\" this weekend. Hmm, maybe I'll do it _now_.<br /><br />I own a lot of cookbooks that seem to have only one or two good recipes. This one clearly doesn't suffer from that affliction.ow_. <br /> <br />I own a lot of cookbooks that seem to have only one or two good recipes. This one clearly doesn't suffer from that affliction.

B0002SROSQ|5.0|This double CD set proves beyond any doubt that Nick Cave is the preeminent musical genius in the world bar none. Who else but Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds could bring along the core punk rock following they established with the Birthday Party, on their trek across the musical landscapes they've traversed over at least 2 decades? Nick Cave is a true lyrical poet, as well as a master of the macabre, a rock-n-roll Edgar Allan Poe. Not to diminish the role of The Bad Seeds, who are brilliant, extraordinary musicians. They make magic together. I just love Warren Ellis. This CD is a must have for any Nick Cave fan, and anyone who appreciates soul music from the vantage point of someone who is intimately acquainted with hell. With this CD, his darkness is more subtle than on others-which still doesn't say a lot given his pitch black humor. It is,as someone said, more joyful but with a melancholic edge, in a way only Nick Cave could do. I don't care for joyful music, or poetry, or literature. Sorry- I don't think I'd be such a huge Nick Cave fan if I did. So- its joyful in a way that somber people can appreciate. Another way I could describe it is the feeling you have when you've experience great loss, and come into happiness again. The euphoria is bittersweet because you know, in your bones, that the eventual loss is inevitable. But since there are 2 CDs, to try to pin the music down in any one way would be false. Its rich, multi-textured, multi-dimensional, and transcendent. The touch of the gospel choir is amazing, although I agree, its a bit too frequent for my taste. Its a small thing. My favorite Nick Cave CD is still No More Shall We Part- because its much more explicitly somber and angry, in a masterfully artistic way. It is a pure work of art. Check it out if you haven't. Anyway- I've never written a review before. I was just so inspired by Nick Cave that I had to share, thank him publicly for existing. Especially in light of the deadly superficiality of the 21st Century. Make sure to catch him live- they put on a mind blowing performance.entury. Make sure to catch him live- they put on a mind blowing performance.
B000002KEV|5.0|I'm pretty sure that \\"Made In Japan\\" was my first live album. The first one I owned, I mean, I wasn't in the band.    I didn't know a whole lot about Deep Purple...only \\"Smoke On The Water\\" would have rung a bell, I guess, but I really liked the album. Still do.   Opening with the punding, up-tempo \\"Highway Star\\", this is vintage Deep Purple. Richie Blackmore's guitar and Jon Lord's characteristic organ are vying for first chair, Purple had one of rock's greatest vocalist in Ian Gillan, and a top-notch rhythm section in drummer Ian Paice and bassist Roger Glover.  \\"Made In Japan\\" was recorded over three nights in 1972, and the band perform selections from \\"Deep Purple In Rock\\", \\"Fireball\\", and their highwater mark \\"Machine Head\\". This may only be a seven-track album, but it runs for over 76 minutes, complete with   numerous solos including a grand drum solo during \\"The Mule\\".    Blending thundering hard rock with strands of jazz, pop and classical music, Purple do a memorable 12-minute \\"Child In Time\\", loose but effective renditions of \\"Strange Kind Of Woman\\" and \\"Smoke On The Water\\", and a driving \\"Space Truckin'\\".   Deep Purple, and their excessive live albums in particular, may be a bit of an acquired taste...there is just as much organ here as there is guitar, and Ian Gillan's vocals may seem hysterical to some. But \\"Made In Japan\\" is a must-have for Purple fans, of course, and while those who are merely curious should probably start off with a good compilation or the \\"Machine Head\\" album, you really should give this one a try as well. This colourful album has a lot to answer for....it played no small part in making hard rock and heavy metal what it is.

B0002OERI0|5.0|The Grammy winning band Green Day first made mainstream success in 1994 with their album \\"Dookie\\".  This gave new and unique visions of punk music with their melodies and lyrics of humorous rebellion.  This trio since became the biggest selling punk act in music history.  Despite that, their mainstream standing began dropping noticably in the late 1990's.  Several fans began losing faith in them.  Many thought this was the end of Green Day. <br /> <br />Then in 2004, they released their fifth major-label album \\"American Idiot\\".  Their four-year interval between their previous album (\\"Warning\\") and this one proved worth the wait.  They return to the spotlight as highly respectful rockers.  Old time fans find new reasons to like them again while new fans introduce themselves to Green Day.  This explores new territory that nobody guessed would come from them.  The album title and its front cover speaks the theme for itself.  Their outspoken, risque political theme continues the legacy started by legendary punk act The Clash.  Yet, Green Day stays true to their signature rock style while adding raunchiness.  Occasionally, they experiment with different genres including 50's rock & roll and psychedelic rock.  Overall, they may have recorded the best album in the careers to date and the best punk-themed album in many years. <br /> <br />Their variety of musical themes blend wonderfully with the overall album theme and the individual song lyrics.  This album tells a story of how this country has been negatively affected by politics.  Disaster, death, drugs, discrimination, and war are only some aspects expressed.  This punk opera begins this powerful story with the song \\"American Idiot\\".  The lyrics and the performance expressions remain powerful throughout, including the two five-song medleys \\"Jesus of Surburbia\\" and \\"Homecoming\\".  The amazing poetry blends perfectly with the musical background.  These words, which few other artists have dared to express, earns them tremendous respect.  Never before has Green Day released an album that holds true unforgettable meaning. <br /> <br />The irateness is wonderfully expressed by all three members through their individual musical talents.  Billy Joe Armstrong gives new and deeper meaning to these lyrics through his powerful and raunchy lead vocals.  Whether he yells or \\"keeps his cool through anger\\", his trueness always prevails.  His guitar work, Mike Dirnt's bass work, and Tre Cool's drum work offer their own input in the theme. <br /> <br />Those who listen to \\"American Idiot\\" should not skip any tracks.  Otherwise, they will miss an important portion of the story.  Meanwhile, this is recommended for all rock and punk fans.  This highly addictive album is sure to please many listeners.  Its powerful message will not lose itself in several listens. <br /> <br />***Expect Green Day to receive at least three 2004 Grammy nominations: Best Rock Album, Best Hard Rock Performance (\\"American Idiot\\"), and Best Rock Song.

B00005JMH2|4.0|A middle-aged lawyer (Richard Gere) battles his ennui by taking ballroom dancing lessons and developing a special relationship with a beautiful, mysterious dance instructor (Jennifer Lopez).  I loved the Japanese original, and I was highly skeptical when I learned that an American remake was being made, especially when I found out who was starring in it.  Gere is not one of my favorite actors and I am thoroughly sick of J. Lo.  However, I was very pleasantly surprised.  J. Lo spends much of the film on the sidelines being mysterious while the marvelous cast of character actors (including Stanley Tucci, Bobby Cannavale, Lisa Ann Walter, and Omar Benson Miller) get a chance to shine.  Gere is really rather charming.  The film depends on the premise that taking ballroom dance lessons could be a source of great shame for a respectable professional.  That works in a Japanese context, but is much less convincing for Americans.  I give director Peter Chelsom and screenwriter Audrey Wells credit for making it as plausible as anyone could.  Just go with it and you will find much to enjoy in this charming film./

B000002UVZ|5.0|Oh well, no matter. No one gets R.E.M. albums for their covers. LIFE'S RICH PAGEANT contains the band's hardest rocking songs, more than a touch of their strange side and brilliant songwriting throughout.<br /><br />I recall having a mixed reaction when this first came out, but I just needed time to let it sink in. Now it's probably my favorite R.E.M. album.<br /><br />I have to disagree with critics who insist the band's best work remains on its first few releases. They claim to love originality while simultaneously praising the derivative qualities of their earliest music (in particular, the Velvet influence).<br /><br />When FABLES came out, some fans were less enthusiastic although I thought it to be their most brilliant one to date. I understand it was a difficult one for the band to record but the results are wonderful. 0375507256|5.0|Wow!  This is Mitchell's third novel and it is as inventive as his previous two.  The pattern of the novel is like Russian dolls: the first story ends with the last section of the novel, the second story ends with the second to last section...  Each story is written with a completely distinct voice and in a different genre.  Each narrative is subtely tied to the narrative that precedes it or follows by the narratives themselvs (on the form of a diary, letters, a novel, a movie, etc.)  In one of the stories we meet a composer working on a sextet called \\"Cloud Atlas Sextet\\", which is written for six distinct yet overlapping voices.  The narrator of that section cannot decide if it is \\"gimmicky or revolutionary\\"?  I know what I think. <br />

B0002Y4TZG|5.0|The Clash were perhaps the very embodiment of true punk, with a far higher level of musical versatility than may have been evident to the casual observer at the time. Joe Strummer and Mick Jones made a formidable songwriting partnership, with both immediacy and depth, and assimilated a huge range of musical influences. They were one of the few collection of musicians without Jamaican origins who could successfully play reggae, or their own punkish re-modelling of reggae, without sounding like an insipid imitation. As well as their own reggae or rasta-inspired Rudie Can't Fail and Jimmy Jazz, its influence is throughout and there are two reggae tunes, Danny Ray's Get Up (as Revolution Rock) and the Rulers' Wrong 'Em Boyo, which begins with a snatch of Johnny Otis' Staggerlee And Billy, just as the Rulers version did.<br /><br />They also cover Vince Taylor's rockabilly classic Brand New Cadillac. When Joe Strummer later sang with the Pogues in place of the ailing Shane MacGowan, it made perfect sense because of the impassioned folk-a-billy sensibilities also inherent in the Clash's music.<br /><br />The name London Calling comes from the call sign of the BBC's 2LO radio news bulletin, dating from 1922, and is apposite as the band send their own front-line bulletins around the globe half-a-century later. The call sign was retained by the World Service, for whom Joe Strummer was later to present record programmes right up to his untimely death.<br /><br />The title song was a single in the UK, though in the USA it became the flip of Train In Vain (Stand By Me). Astonishingly, the dazzling Train In Vain was originally written and recorded to be a free cover-mounted single for the New Musical Express, and appeared on the album as a last-minute undocumented extra track when that didn't happen.<br /><br />The double-album London Calling is an enduring masterpiece, though some of its sonic subtleties were lost in the original vinyl mastering, and far from being locked in a seventies time warp, the record sounds valid and meaningful today.<br /><br />The original re-mastered CD rectified many of the vinyl shortcomings, bringing out parts of the musical palette that had previously sounded dull, and this new re-master is at least its equal, and often superior. It also sounds leaner, as the 3-second pauses between the tracks have been excised, hence the abbreviated running time.<br /><br />The Vanilla tapes are demos recorded at a rehearsal studio in Pimlico, made in the final month before album recording proper got underway at Wessex in July 1979. Believed lost for many years they acquired legendary status, partly because Joe Strummer had at one time intimated that the demos might actually become the album, though this was mostly gamesmanship with the record label, as the sound quality is not of a releasable quality for that purpose. It is are a fascinating document of a series of songs in development, though; valuable to those with a serious interest in the band. I imagine it is disc one that will find its way back to my CD tray most frequently, but it is of course nice to have, along with the booklet, a facsimile of the original album insert and a bonus DVD, in a well presented packagerp, the record sounds valid and meaningful today. <br />The original re-mastered CD rectified many of the vinyl shortcomings, bringing out parts of the musical palette that had previously sounded dull, and this new re-master is at least its equal, and often superior. It also sounds leaner, as the 3-second pauses between the tracks have been excised, hence the abbreviated running time. <br />The Vanilla tapes are demos recorded at a rehearsal studio in Pimlico, made in the final month before album recording proper got underway at Wessex in July 1979. Believed lost for many years they acquired legendary status, partly because Joe Strummer had at one time intimated that the demos might actually become the album, though this was mostly gamesmanship with the record label, as the sound quality is not of a releasable quality for that purpose. It is are a fascinating document of a series of songs in development, though; valuable to those with a serious interest in the band. I imagine it is disc one that will find its way back to my CD tray most frequently, but it is of course nice to have, along with the booklet, a facsimile of the original album insert and a bonus DVD, in a well presented package

0743201140|5.0|If you are used to reading about complex topics, you will have no trouble reading this book in two hours--it is not exactly intellectually thoroughgoing, and indeed some of its sidelines, such as the one on neurology, are so shallow that they could just as well have been left out. But apart from that criticism (or is it a criticism that a book can be read in two hours?) I only can recommend this book for its simple, but important and empowering insights. <br /> <br />Firstly, there is the observation that much of our vocabulary to describe personal differences is about weaknesses and defects and that it is high time to talk about strengths as well. Secondly, we have the insight that in order to develop what corporate strategists would call competitive advantage it is more efficient to develop strengths than to eliminate weaknesses. Both insights are quite common-sensical once you've read them, but utterly lacking in our culture. These two insights alone well justify the purchase price of the book. Together with the code for an online personality profiling of your strengths, the purchase price, the two hours it takes to read the book, and the 30 minutes to take the test will be an excellent investment for almost anyone.

0451529308|5.0|MY SYNOPSIS: <br />The Marchs are the picture of a happy home: with conscientious and righteous Father, who is serving the Union cause as a chaplain, and wise and generous Marmee, who watches over her girls with love and care.  Then there's the little women: sixteen-year-old Meg, who is pretty and mature; free-spirited, fiery Jo, who is determined to become a famous writer; timid Beth, who always puts others before herself; and young Amy with her artistic tastes and airs.  There's also the March's lonely neighbor, Theodre Laurence (Laurie), who befriends the girls and supplements their experiences and family. <br /> <br /> <br />MY REVIEW: This heartwarming story about four sisters growing up during the Civil War visits upon themes of family, transcendence, sincerity, and duty.  In a novel based upon her own family and experiences, Louisa May Alcott chronicles the first of three books about the March family, which is the universal story of the family unit and the self in the face of the world: how each lives and how happiness prevails in morality and truth. <br /> <br />          Alcott's novel caters to all audiences, regardless of age and gender.  As a children's book, as it is often placed, Little Women serves as a record of the coming-of-age of four girls as: Amy bears injustice at school, Jo struggles with personal, literary, and romantic issues, Meg faces society and Vanity Fair, and as life threats Beth's solitude.  As a piece of classic literature, Little Women serves testimony to the emerging conscious and individual.  It's impossible to resist the gentle lessons and the charming, dimensional characters that stimulate the reader to the same awakening and discovery of value.

A blissfully optimistic misfit three times the size of his adopted elf family, Buddy ultimately makes his way (in full elf regalia) to Manhatten, his birth city, where he meets his dad, a Scrooge-like James Caan and cynical eight-year-old half-brother who doesn't even believe in Santa.<br /><br />But worst of all, Elf realizes no one appears to have surrendered to the true meaning of Chritmas -- which we must assume here means innocence and selfless love.  Buddy has his work cut out for him in a series of always surprising, sometimes wild set pieces that never become sappy or smarmy or sentimental.<br /><br />It ocurred to me that Farrell plays Elf as slightly retarded or mentally challenged or maybe he has Aspergers Syndrome, a form of autism that makes a person single mindedly focused (obessesed really) and oblivious to acceptable, ordinary social interactions.<br /><br />Directed by Jon Favreau (\\"Made,\\" \\"Swingers\\"), the film co-stars Mary Steenburgen, Zooey Deschanel, Bob Newhart, Peter Dinklage, and Ed Asner as Santa Claus.<br /><br />The two disc Infinifilm version is jam-packed with watchable extras, deleted scenes, commentaries, behind the scenes featurettes, games and DVD-ROM content. 0684803356|4.0|Half of this book is a brilliant, visceral portrayal of war and the men and women who are swept up in it. It shows the different ways through which men confront their own mortality, and exposes the inherent dirtiness and corruption of war, and how this destroys hope and idealism.  <br />While some right-wing critics of this novel accuse Hemingway of romanticizing Communism, anyone who actually reads the book can see that this is simply not the case. On several occasions, the novel's main character, Robert Jordan, a volunteer soldier in the International Brigades, flashes back to his time in Madrid. In these flashbacks, we see how Robert became disillusioned with Marxist doctrine after seeing the extent of Soviet control and corruption that was rampant in the city, and how the Soviets lied to the Spanish people. One of these flashbacks includes a thinly veiled reference to the Moscow show trials, when a Soviet journalist mentions the name of Zinoviev, an executed Bolshevik, to Robert. Hemingway also shows how Communist Party structure doomed the Republican effort through the character of Andre Marty, a paranoid, inept French Communist leader who, in his power and stupidity, assigned men to impossible missions.   <br />It is shown that most of the left-wing Republican fighters were anti-Communist socialists who simply wanted to be free and to be governed fairly. Hemingway even manages to insert a criticism of American racism, when, after being told a story of how the guerilla group he has joined attacked a village and allowed the inhabitants to murder their right-wing neighbors, Robert recalls a childhood experience of seeing a black man lynched by a group of whites (this part of the story may have been inspired by Hemingway's friendship with the black poet Langston Hughes). <br />If this book was nothing more than the parts that I just described, I would have awarded it five stars. <br /> <br />However, roughly half of this book is the horribly unconvincing love story of Robert Jordan and Maria, a girl who the guerilla band saved from the Fascist forces. Maria is a flat, one-dimensional character whose only goal appears to be to submit to Robert's wishes and to pleasure him. She is weak-willed, and, for the most part, air-headed. These parts of the book drag terribly, and their only redeeming quality is Hemingway's beautiful, vivid descriptions of the mountains of Spain. For these failings, I am forced to say that this novel does not deserve five stars.

0321213351|3.0|This book is the only one of its kind that tries to use a patterns approach to refactoring. It is a good add-on to Martin Fowler's book. It's a very valuable contribution to the refactoring community. Kerievsky has a no-nonsense, down-to-earth approach to the subject of Patterns. However unlike Fowler who makes an effort to keep the code examples in his book as simple as possible, Kerievsky has made his examples over-complicated with all kinds of detailed finance domain references and the XML DOM. The example he uses to show how the Builder pattern simplifies creation of Composites is like a really heavy chapter on XML processing/generation.  <br />The \\"Replace Conditional Logic with Strategy\\" is like a chapter on Investments / Loans. It really distracts the reader's attention from the pattern or refactoring. <br />This is a shame because it is impossible to write a good book on refactoring without nice examples. It is also a bit surprising that none of the other Amazon reviews mention this issue.
